title: District Maintenance Manager
pros: AMH is a place that you can advance your career if you put forth an effort in your own personal development. I started in an entry level position and was able to quickly advance to a mid management position. Eventually, I was able to land a role managing a larger business unit.
cons: To start, work and life balance is non-existent. Every day you must make a choice between your job and your family. If you have children and want to be in management with this company then you better be prepared to make a choice. What is that choice? I'm glad you asked...You have to be willing to sacrifice time with your family. The mountain of work never stops, and the only way to have precious moments with your loved ones is to force a hard stop at a certain point in your day, spend time with them, then get back to work again. (And yes, I am a huge believer in time and calendar management. So if you think you can balance your way out of it, you may need to look elsewhere.) Team Morale - Team morale will almost always be an issue, especially if you manage a field team. Senior level leadership seems to think field employees are expendable, and even if you have a good employee you can just jack another one in their place and get the same results. Unfortunately, this type of mindset is something that leads to management headaches as you are in a constant personnel churn which makes your managers have to step in and fill the void in their team. What does this do to your Field Managers?...Yet another great question. Well, most Field Managers are the best and brightest that came from the field, and they are typically on the edge of burnout and utter frustration. So if you put them in a position to fail and expect them to be at their best, you will likely have some of your team brushing up their resume, or at least reaching out to you several times per week so you can talk them out of leaving the company. There are several other CONS to working for this company, but this isn't the place for novel writing, so I will keep it to this brief description. Also, it wasn't all bad. I made several life long friends, and the local team that I worked with will always feel like a second family to me...You know who you are

They are processors, highly micromanaged and a catch all for escalations, many of which could be avoided if the company took more care in streamlining drawn out processes and overall efficacy. The company strains both the field and PM departments by setting high expectations while providing very few resources to complete tasks in a timely and quality manner. It’s as if they only care about making money, not doing the job efficiently. Many of the Atlanta property managers and field team members are overwhelmed and feel burned out. The company is too successful financially to not adequately staff and support this market area. Both the field and property management teams can use more help. If they valued their employees as they pretend to, they wouldn’t feel burned out.

title: Great opportunities, continuously growing company, and room for advancement within
pros: Great opportunities with room to grow in your career. Great and positive work environment. Empowering and uplifting teams and management. My manager always sets me up for future success. I enjoy the fast paced environment and that each day brings a different challenge to overcome. Great for anyone wanting to be a part of one of the fastest growing and upcoming company's. Great benefits and bonus structures available in some positions. Performance truly pays off.
cons: Sometimes long hours to get the job done but Property management never sleeps. Some turnover, company is a fast paced environment and turnover is due to employees not wanting to put in the effort as this is a culture not just a job. Policy and procedural changes aren't always communicated clearly.

title: Just A Matter of Time
pros: Steady Paycheck and decent benefits
cons: Where do I begin...I work in Charlotte Region and the Favoritism shown in this office is astounding, but this seems to be a company standard. Management and District management are totally incompetent. It doesnt get any better at the Senior level either. For someone that has been in management for years, how do you place people with “NO” experience what so ever in leadership roles??? You had a great office with great people and that’s why the office worked and now we see what happens when good people are trashed. What management did to a past employee to ruin one of the top Agents in the company and have his credibility and image ruined. To have the Police called, clear the office and FIRE a GREAT employee is outrageous! HR is a joke by not protecting the VICTIM of another employee. SHAMEFUL! I hope this is brought to light and the company is held accountable. As you probably can tell, I’m looking elsewhere. Avoid this company at all cost.

title: Future is great but there are growing pains
pros: Don't just think outside the box, toss the box away and imagine what the rental market will look like in 30 years because that's what is being created; changing the landscape of the industry; great hours; solid benefits; expanding employment opportunities

pros: Not enough to recommend giving up your life for
cons: Too many to mention here

pros: The people in the corporate headquarters in Agoura Hills are cool. It's a pretty laid back environment with minimal micro-managing.
cons: They don't care about their employees or their employees growth. Little to no room to grow. This company has huge capital and it would be nice if they appreciated their employees more, even if it's just by doing team outings every once in a while. There's also a lot of people who should have been fired a LONG time ago, but still manage to have a job there and get by by doing the bare minimum. title: If you enjoy laid back and easy money

The company does not value their employees and there's no room for growth unless you know someone there. There is no proper training, so everyone teaches each other in hopes that one day they will have it all together. If you are looking for more opportunities within the company, you will not find it here. If you ever seek to want a day off because you've been busting your butt for 13 hour days and 6 days a week, good luck in getting management to approve your time off. They would have you sleep there if there was enough room to lodge.

title: Great company to work for!
pros: In the short amount of time I have worked for American Homes 4 Rent, I have learned a great deal about the company and my field. My manager is incredibly supportive of continuing education as she encourages her team to attend seminars and webinars to increase our job related and general knowledge in our field. She will allow us to work from home if we have appointments, become ill or just need a no distraction environment to work on a time sensitive project. My team is supportive of each other and works well together. It is refreshing to have a team and manager that want you to grow and succeed in your career!
cons: AH4R is growing quickly and the work environment is fast paced. Since the company is fairly new, policies and procedures are still being fined tuned. I think every company has areas for improvement and I can see that AH4R is working hard make those improvements.

title: Misrepresentations
pros: There are no pros for working with this company.

You can’t be sick. There is no “team” unity. They are all about the numbers. They allow discrimination and poor treatment of Employees. Favoritism is a KEY factor in this company, performance does not matter, it is about who you know.

title: Homebuilding and New Communities for AH4R
pros: I have worked for a couple of the big name homebuilders and I can honestly say that joining the AMH Development team of AH4R is one of the best career decisions I have made. The product we build is consistent and we build all the homes for the same customer - OURSELVES! Our production pace is steady and we didn't even flinch during the COVID craziness this Spring. AH4R is a strong company financially (53,000 homes owned!) and I like that we are leading the way our newly built Communities of rental homes.
cons: truction - new homes

title: Everyday is a challenge I WILLINGLY ACCEPT
pros: American Homes 4 Rent is an outstanding place to work , in which not only do they compensate their employees AT or ABOVE market average , offer OT hours when needed , they provide more than enough tools and resources to get the job done , all the meanwhile you get to further educate yourself using the mission-critical tool , University training ..
cons: For me , the biggest negativity about working at AH4R thus far , would be the lack of bonus or incentive-structure .

title: Great Company with lots of Growth Opportunities
pros: I've worked for AH4R for the last two years and have truly enjoyed every bit of it. Yes, there are stressful times (that's property management) but management is always there for you. The office environment is pleasant and I look forward to coming to work and seeing my coworkers. For being a relatively new company, I'm very impressed by how well they have their stuff together. There has been a lot of growth and I've witnessed several promotions as a result of the growth.

pros: The group of guys you work with is one of the best I've ever worked with. They are all willing to jump in and help when you need help. Very outgoing and fun group of individuals with a lot of integrity.

title: Worst technology ever

title: Fast-paced and good work/life balance
pros: My ability to produce quality work quickly and keep calm in the very fast-paced environment has served me well here. I get to work with up-to-date software and a variety of programs everyday. Coming from academia/gov't that's a huge deal. No more just making it work with 15 year old tech!! My experience has been that management is willing to hear new ideas and have open discussions. Sure, the company tries out new stuff because they're the first to do what they're doing and there are growing pains. But good work is rewarded and I have a healthy work/life balance. How many other corporations are offering that these days??
cons: I have no issues here. Perhaps more parking, but that's no deterrent by any means.

title: Love the Morale!
pros: I love the Call Center environment! This is an easy job as long as you are willing to put in the effort. Friendly competition set by managers is fun. I love when we are able to get together outside of work for bowling and karaoke. We build relationships with our co-workers that way. I mean, you are at work more than home so they are family. At the end of the year, we celebrate each other and our accomplishments by attending a lavish Awards Dinner at the Palms. The food is delicious and the company is even better. The managers really show they care about you.
cons: Cost of family plan with benefits. I know that is the cost of insurance, but I wish it was cheaper.

title: Great opportunities at a booming company.
pros: AH4R is a great place to work with management that values its employees and tries to make work fun and engaging. The Company is constantly sponsoring fun events and encourages friendly competition. Although the company has a lot of employees, it feels like a smaller business with how quickly you get to know everyone. AH4R is an industry leader and with how much it continues to grow, opportunities are endless.
cons: With a company that leads the way in many areas and is constantly growing, there are frequent changes. You can either adapt to the changes, or struggle, but your success depends on whether you are up for the challenge or not.

title: Huge Opportunities and a Fantastic Company
pros: American Homes for Rent offers an incredible opportunity for career advancement in an abbreviated time period. Fresh and new ideas are welcomed and you have the ability to implement them to make a difference. Hard work is recognized and rewarded. It is truly a fast paced job that positively challenges you professionally. You will grow and refine all of your management skills. It is a very unique opportunity to be a part of a company this exciting and a pleasure and an honor to work here.
cons: This company is dynamic and fast paced. Personally, this is a pro for my personality type. As the company grows, changes are implemented and you have to be able to adapt.

title: How about using Property Management Professionals to run a Property Management business?
pros: Benefits are good. Never a boring moment. Some upper level employees have a true understanding of sincere appreciation and positive reinforcement (many amazing people to work with). They are learning and trying to improve. Lots of forward movement. I love working where I am needed, and I feel very needed at the company. I feel that I am truly contributing to the future of our industry and to our company (granted, more listening would be appreciated). The HR department is fantastic.
cons: Most positions come with a side order of high blood pressure. Too much secrecy. Employees are kept in the dark for no reason which only induces an environment of distrust, coupled with a weariness about future/current job security. I have witnessed inappropriate gossiping and unprofessional behavior demonstrated by upper management on multiple occasions (this may only apply to my direct managers). Promotions and recognition seem to stem from friendships rather than from merit, experience, or any other valid metric. Far too centralized! You cannot take away the Property Managers primary job functions and give them to someone who knows nothing about the industry and expect a positive outcome. DMs and PMs have been reduced to being collection agents (only they don’t get paid a commission like a typical collection agent does) because they are repairing the damage caused by substandard underwriting. Property Managers and District Managers are made to humiliate themselves by apologizing to countless tenants for the mistakes made by the maintenance department, accounting, the IT department and their glitches with tenant portals and on and on. PMs and DMs are also made to be the in between guy for tenants and the company, which essentially just turns them into stressed out, full time punching bags. It’s disturbing that the departments who claim their power over their specific job duties won’t be held accountable for any of their own mistakes or decisions. Real examples: The auto payments did not process this month. PMs must call all tenants with auto pay, apologize for the “technical glitch” and ask them to make their payment. PM tells accounting not to charge these tenants late fees, but they do anyway. PM now calls tenants again, apologizes for the late fees/notice fees that accounting charged them and then begs someone else to reverse said charges and crosses their fingers that it is actually done. Pricing department sends out a renewal to a top notch tenant with a massive rent increase. Tenant had many unresolved maintenance requests throughout the year, and even without that, the home is already overpriced. Tenant calls PM irate (because pricing won’t speak to the tenant). PM apologizes and says they will requests a decrease in the price and get back to them. PM requests decrease. Pricing denies it. PM calls tenant and apologizes- again… and so on. Is there some mysterious reason the pricing department is not willing to be accountable for the decisions they deliberately excluded the Property Management Professionals from? What sense is there in wasting the PM’s time with: tenant to PM- PM to pricing- pricing to PM- PM back to tenant? Same situation with most other departments. Tenant to PM (because tenant is not getting their maintenance situation resolved), PM to maintenance, maintenance to vendor, vendor to maintenance, maintenance to PM, PM to tenant….. no wonder it’s not being done… It took two days just to ask a simple question and relay the answer back to the tenant.

title: promotion and acknowledgment of hard work
pros: The best thing about this company is they really do work as a team from top to bottom and even though they have to constantly scrutinize your work it also gives you great opportunities to grow and get on the fast track to promotions and greater responsibilities. You will not toil unnoticed for years, your hard work will be seen immediately and rewarded.If you thrive in a self starting environment and are looking to be upwardly mobile AH4R is the company for you.
cons: On the same note If a person is lazy and not constantly looking to improve themselves or the company that will also be seen and notated.

title: I love working for this company
pros: Great projects, lots of places to make an impact, working with intelligent people, travel, dynamic issues, every day is different. I wake up every day excited to come to work because i know the work i'm doing makes a difference. We laugh, we complain, we have fun, and we work. The last 6 months of my employment have shown me that work can be fun and you see that every old person who has said "do something you love" was right. Life is so much better when you love your job, and i feel blessed to have the chance to experience that everyday.
cons: general growing pains that happen with a startup in hypergrowth mode. some projects are repetitive, interoffice politics, long hours when needed, this company is not a 9-5 company.

title: Thankful
pros: As my headline states, I am so thankful that my friend brought me on board with this company. It will be 2 years in April and I wake up every day thankful, happy and appreciative of the work I am able to do. I've had the opportunity to grow in my career and as an individual since coming aboard. It's so amazing to know that you have purpose in the work that you do and to know that you are fully supported and appreciated by not only your team but also your superiors all the way up to the executives of the company.

Each department is equipped and willing to welcome anyone into the fold. It's open, transparent and full of sharing best practices and working together. I felt valued and part of the team from day one. I can't imagine being any where else.

cons: The only downside is currently being addressed. There are multiple systems required in each department to be able to complete certain tasks, and having the systems integrated together would make every department more efficient. Our Executive Team has recognized this as an opportunity and has implemented huge changes that have already been felt throughout all markets.

All meetings are blurred with ever changing chaos with fakes walking around. Fake leaders who lie to your face and stab you in the back. No onboarding or ramp up time provided. The worst part of all is THEY DON'T CARE ABOUT THE RESIDENT TENANT living in the house. pros: We have access to all cutting edge technology which allows everyone to learn new things and systems. Good hours, good pay and decent benefits. AH4R is a good place to work if you want to apply your knowledge and grow.

title: Love my new job!
pros: I am fairly new here but felt like I was an important part of the team since day one! My interview experience and first week has been nothing but positive and everyone has been so professional and welcoming. The tools they provided were excellent for my training and my team is very positive and a happy bunch! I know I made the right choice by working here!! Also, the office is beautiful and coffee is excellent!
cons: There are a lot of spreadsheets but I think that is because my team is fairly new so with time things could change and consolidate. Other than that, I can't think of any cons as I love this place!

We were told in an all department meeting that "If you disagree with the way we're doing things, talk to me and I'll tell you why you're wrong."

title: We've come a long way
pros: If you want to work for a fast paced company where you are given the tools and it is up to you to succeed. You are given a lot of growth opportunities and the company has been very fair to me these past 3 years. I enjoy the people I work with and for. AH4R is literally creating the model for this type of business.
cons: I wished we had a local office. We've had some growing pains, but we will get better as we mature as a company.

title: Property Manager
pros: Good health insurance - If you have Any other option, take it. Believe what you read. It's all true. Gave it one star because 0 wasn't an option.
cons: Unrealistic expectations from inexperienced manager. I watched illegal activities among upper management, which only received a wrist slap and then a promotion. A poor excuse for a property management company. If you happen to have friends there who hire you, you can expect to receive raises and bonuses, and promotions, even if you're not qualified. I was told, a number of times, to "say anything" to get people to pay the rent. I wished I'd known more about the company before I'd signed on. I know for a fact that the positive comments are made by higher ups in the company.

title: One star
pros: 1 hour lunch breaks and good pay.

title: A job that will make you love waking up everyday
pros: Great company that truly cares about your well being, will offer training to help you grow as a person, and offers new opportunities to internal candidates before reaching out to external candidates. In the few years I have been with AH4R, I have moved up the ranks from initially a temp in Accounting, to a Purchase Specialist, then a Field Coordinator, to now a Trade Services Manager. This company has truly changed my life and the culture is so upbeat, I would recommend anyone looking for a great company to grow with to apply.
cons: You have to be quick on your feet and be able to adjust to change quite frequently, I personally enjoy the fast pace and I am never bored.

title: My experience so far with AH4R
pros: Starting off at a new job can be a bit intimidating, especially if you don't really know the ins and the outs of the workplace, but AH4R is different. It's different in that everyone that works her welcome you with a big smile no matter where you are. I know that saying "it's like one big family" is a cliché but this place really is like that. Aside from the friendliness of your coworkers the bosses are just as great. All in all, I have more than enjoyed the transition into AH4R.

title: American Feudalism 4 Real
pros: - Stable income, reverse robinhood model (take from the poor, give to the rich) and inevitable long-term growth strategy - Destroying the American dream to make a lot of foreign investors richer while labelling it a patriotic venture
cons: - Demoralizing pay and culture - Toxic management and belligerent behavior by executives - Terrible productivity, disrespectful and clueless management that treats people and tenants ruthlessly like peasants - Nasty PR/legal issues, hard to take pride in being a part of a company that says its helping people while raising rents and justifying more American families living in poverty without a way to get out from buying a home themselves - Business model and industry is becoming increasingly saturated/competitive with greed from larger global investors with too much money to spend on bad investments

title: Steer Clear! Trust me!
pros: Great money (see detailed explanation) and decent benefits.

Get bodies in houses pretty much. Get them in and then we drop the ball left and right leaving extremely angry tenants which is stressful because you leased the house to them and they have your number and email! Like being threatened? Join! Now as far as income, you will make money. HOWEVER when you factor in all the hours you WILL work, you're really not making that great of an income. Work/life balance? None. Now please believe me when I tell you that I am not some Whitney agent that wants to work bankers hours. I'm no stranger to hard work. But 70 hour work weeks? Every week? And this is intense, non stop stress, non stop fires to put out hours. Like how did 10 hours fly by and I haven't eaten hours. It's not worth it. Especially if you have a family. It's not worth it. I've actually given notice and so I decided to write a review to help the next person. I've neglected my family for almost two years for the sake of this job. I wouldn't even refer people to rent their homes as they do not do right by residents and maintenance is terrible. The corporate office and other offices are filled with people that are in positions that they shouldn't be in because their mom and dad are I high positions. Moms, dads, cousins, best friends, spouses, brothers, etc.... If they were experienced and deserved the position, I'm all for it! But 22 year old VP's? People in charge of pricing real estate that are in Vegas and want to price Florida inventory and they have no idea of the market conditions or even have a clue about real estate! No career path unless you're willing to relocate to a crappy market that needs all the help they can get. I could go on and on but I'll stop here. I wish I could be available for questions but sadly I can't. I'll end with, there are other similar companies that are better ran than this one. Steer clear.

title: Great company with lots of potential for growth if you can get a good manager.
pros: Growth opportunities, great culture depending on what department you're in, gain valuable knowledge to grow your own wealth in rental investments.

title: Poorly ran company do not rent from them or work for them!
pros: Zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero zero

pros: Pay is good, benefits package is nice, local office has a laid back atmosphere, majority of staff are interesting to working with and friendly enough.
cons: Company attitude and atmosphere leaves much to be desired. PM' s, DM's and FM's are in roles they clearly aren't experienced enough to have and then aren't provided proper training or educational incentives. Lack of true professionalism and rules apply to some and not to others; seemingly dependent on the daily agenda of "upper" management. Inconsistency in practices and rules in terms what each employee is allowed to do, but that depends on whom you are "friends" with. There is no true focus on customer relations and no efforts being made to improve them in the foreseeable future. All staff members with exception of few are constantly overwhelmed and have to wear multiple hats. Inability to get many issues addressed to your satisfaction and that of those served because much of the companies operations are split between several different people. Input from those that best know the market is rarely taken into consideration. Opportunities for promotion is seem to be non-existent unless you are favored by someone in upper management. Your experience, work-ethic, professionalism, education, track record with the company and other merits are not considered. Need for more staff and new positions.

title: Terrible management; Nepotism is rampant.
pros: Flexible schedule sometimes, great coworkers.
cons: Elite rich guys running company only think of themselves. They hire minimum-wage workers to run everything about the company that the rest the employees depend on. Local management takes care of their own race and religion while burying everyone else. Extremely burdensome workload. No complaints are heard. HR complaints are not anonymous.

title: They Try Hard
pros: Good Benefits, decent pay. Good location. Multiple shifts.
cons: Immature management, bonus structure has never been adequately explained and appears to be a great mystery, decided by popularity. Always demanding mandatory overtime and they never seem satisfied with your best efforts.

title: Maintenance
pros: Nothing Nice At All.
cons: What a Deplorable place to work. Managers are put on pedistals and treat employess with zero respect. They lie on employess to cover their short comings while it devours employees life and career. There is no room for advancement. You are given leasing agents job responsibilities and headaches while they sit in the office and do nothing to collect their 6 figure salaries. There is NO training. I would not recommend this company to anyone!

title: Excellent company with a great work culture.
pros: Fantastic experience working at AH4R. The work culture is the best I've seen in the 10+ years of my career. Of course we stay busy, that's the nature of managing a property portfolio of this size. But it feels good to work for a company that cares so much about it's employees and residents. Each day I feel thankful to work on a team of industry leaders in an organization that cares about us. We are supported and empowered and valued it makes it a rewarding work experience. Could not ask for more in my career.
cons: I honestly cannot think of a single one.

title: AH4R Employment
pros: I started with the company in late 2014 as an Administrative assistant. There is so much room for promotion within the company. 7 Years later and I am in a senior management position. The company cares about the wellbeing of your work and home life. This isn't your normal corporate company, all the the senior leadership all the way up to the CEO listen to the needs of it employees.
cons: Its a ton of work that you have to have a particular mental mindset to be able to handle.

title: Keep Looking
pros: Casual dress code (Jeans all week long for most people including management) and really nice funny co-workers. Work is very dynamic so you will learn here.
cons: Opportunities for raises or advancement are scarce and insulting no matter how long and hard you work here. HR works in the executives interest only and everyone knows it. Compensation is all over the place (very demoralizing).

title: Horribly Managed
pros: Benefits and for field employees flexible to get some work done at home
cons: The company throws people to the wolves, constantly setting people up for failure. Everything is done backwards and perfection is expecfes. There is nothing that they will stop at to save a dime. Everyone is out for themselves and step on other employees toes if it means making themselves look good. The pay is decent but not for the amount of work and the extent its done in. Policies change weekly, which in a newer company it can happen, but there is no support system and upper management could care less. A Work/home life balance is VERY hard to get and keep in a good place.

title: Don’t expect to gain loads of experience here
pros: - Skilled Upper management and solid, reliable company who really is an industry leader. - There are not as many people are getting fired for non-performance related issued but it’s still not uncommon - The company provides decent benefits & Paid time off but well below average 401k contributions. - Easy place to do a below average job and earn a wage slightly above the poverty line if you keep your head down, don’t ask questions and don’t tick off the wrong person. - Oftentimes skilled people are hired but they fall into the keep your head down attitude which stems from the top down. - Very supportive of women and minorities in the workplace. - Good work-life balance – You’re not allowed over time so little concern for work on the weekends.
cons: - Huge separation between management and hourly/ salary workers regarding pay & status within the organization. Don’t expect a High five from David Singelyn any time soon… - Very little input is desired from the common workforce while disconnected senior managers confusingly attempt to make changes to the corporate culture. (We had an employee survey 2 years back, there were No follow up surveys and little to no changes made.) - Keep your head down and do your work attitude which stems from the top down. - There are essentially Zero opportunities or growth paths. If you are hired, expect to do your current job for 5 years + with typically 3% annual raises from below average starting wages. - Zero education or learning opportunities provided. No college reimbursement or opportunities to teach yourself. Don’t expect to gain loads of experience here. Middle management that is promoted aren’t given any leadership or management coaching outside of some online tutorials. - Communication is horrible. Managers will randomly be let go and people will only find out when they go to send an email or hear the gossip across the floor. Employee focused calls miss the mark and spend time welcoming new employees rather than emphasizing strategic steps for change or important corporate notices. - Recruiters routinely lie on the phone to prospective applicants – Which should be a huge red flag to management. - Be prepared to work in a completely dead quiet office with little collaboration among employees. Employee council is offered however it fails to institute any change.

title: A disgrace to the Residential Leasing Industry.
pros: Experience on what NOT to do in Property Management.
cons: No Support for Management or Staff, Serious lack of communication, no resolution guidance , poor training, poor leadership, poor quality of service. Instead, upper management seeks knowledge from employees on how to handle a situation instead of giving property guidance and delegation. upper management lacks respect for employees .

title: I have found my HOME within my position...
pros: I have worked for a few companies in my lifetime. Even ones I never thought I'd leave, but due to position elimination and closing of a business, I have found myself at AH4R. I LOVE my job. I truly do. I love going to work and growing with a newer company. I take pride in what I do and expect to be here for the long run.
cons: Every company has growing pains. AH4R is no exception. However, it's great to grow with the company and find the Do's and Dont's as well as creating new solutions and implementing new ideas that makes it exciting.

title: Possibilities are endless
pros: AH4R is a great company with extreme room for growth. They have full benefit packages that in my opinion you can't beat. They truly care about your health and work/ life balance. They offer a free program in which you can utilize for anything regarding your life, (finances, family planning, mental health, etc;) I highly recommend working here. I'm grateful to be a part of such an awesome team, and to be growing within a phenomenal company.
cons: The only Con I've experienced is miscommunication from employees from time to time.

pros: I've been with American Homes 4 Rent for awhile and have found its a great company to work for. They're very flexible on hours and allow for a family work balance.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth but it's still a start up company. Only con is that fear of lack of job security causes management to instill stress on its subordinates. High turnover rate due to instability at times. Not a whole lot of communication between departments

title: Incredible Team and Company
pros: Growth Opportunity; Management is always happy to help and ensure that every employee has the tools necessary to grow, not just within the company but life in general. Teams/managers ensure success is achieved. Coworkers that truly care for their teams well being. Incredible culture. Day to day collaboration with other teams/departments. Freedom to deploy new programs without micromanagement.
cons: Motorcycles can take entire parking space, due to lack of motorcycle parking.

title: UNPROFESSIONAL with a capital U
pros: Absolutely None. They were not ready for employees nor were they training employees on their company policies and procedures correctly. They were made up as they went along offering no continuity or structure.
cons: Inadequate training, unprofessional and rude mid level management, Upper level property management was rude, unresponsive to confidentially expressed unfair working conditions, on one occasion management was drinking alcoholic beverages while working and on several occasions; and repeatedly upper level and mid management used profane language with inappropriate voice levels. Just completely and utterly the most unprofessional, untrained, disorganized, unprepared management staff and work environment.

title: Thrilled to Be Part of Building This Company!!
pros: * Opportunity to create the infrastructure for my area of responsibility * Collaborative, Highly Talented Team Members to work with * Being part of not only a new company but also a new industry * Every day offers a new challenge to solve
cons: This is definitely not the place for someone who wants to simply follow standard policies and procedures. We are basically a very large start-up and creating the infrastructure to support our crazy fast growth!

title: Great Company...Wonderful Co-workers
pros: Team atmosphere. There is always help if you need it from an amazing support staff. Personal and employment growth. Flexibility. Family oriented.
cons: Where there is growth there is lots of change. Sometimes the structural changes can cause anxiety. You have to really be able to adapt to handle the wonderful changes in this industry.

title: Amazing Company, Evolving Strong Culture, Positive and Prosperous Vision and Strategy
pros: perous Vision and Strategy
cons: - At times seasonal workload can get intense - Highly regulated industry

The management at AH4R is really understanding and willing to work with you and actually make you feel like your part of the team. I definitely see myself here 10+ years down the road.

title: Sr. Manager

The CEO is too high and mighty to even say "hello" or "hi" as you pass him in the hall even on weekends when the air conditioner is not on and your the only one present.

title: I Love the Energy
pros: Flexibility of Schedule (at least in my department) Work from home Always able to get my requested days off Bonus incentives Positive energy flows around every department Always looking to improve what we do. Job security I can keep going all day long!! but for me the MOST important thing is my time, and with this company I was able to work hard towards getting the schedule I wanted, in the environment I wanted and they have the flexibility for requesting days off that I needed. Great over all
cons: There's always change, just when you starting getting use to something there is a new process or new software.

title: Steer Clear
pros: Business casual attire; denim, sandals, tanks, and tees. (hardly business casual)
cons: The staff is poorly trained and management has no clue what they are doing. Supervisors confide and vent to own employees about other employees and coworkers. No specific training manual. Employees get in trouble for asking too many questions. Employees are expected to complete months of work within a days time. Employees let go when they bring their issues to management

title: Every interaction is different
pros: + Excellent benefits + Fun/Relaxed work environment + Work load is manageable if you can prioritize and multi-task.
cons: - Only real issue that I see is although I've been with the company over a year & have been recognized as a top performer several times, still no change in base compensation

title: Opportunistic company that does not value employees
pros: Flexibility in schedule, able to work from home
cons: To many Chiefs, not enough Indians, Company culture of mistrust in all employees, they want to manage everything from Las Vegas and don't empower employees to think, use common sense, and resolve issues directly. Power struggles between different levels of management that only worsen bureaucracy. Too much redundancy in all processes. Politics to the maximum level and unqualified people allowed to have too much saying in areas they know nothing about. No team environment, everyone is encouraged to throw each other under the bus as long as it makes them look better.

title: Great Opportunity
pros: American Homes 4 Rent is growing at an extreme rate. This allows everyone to make an immediate impact by suggesting and implementing new process changes. The management is very helpful in fostering employees that drive to improve the company. In my seven months working here I have seen many employees promoted from within. They do a great job recruiting and hiring talent!
cons: The company has grown up so fast that changes are required to remain efficient.

title: Great place to learn about real estate management
pros: Excellent group of professionals in the finance department. The company is one of the largest players in the industry. This will give you exposure to various facets of the sector.
cons: High turnover causes some difficulty getting acclimated to the environment and performing at top efficiency. This environment might also create a level of stress that's not easily acceptable to everyone.

title: Great Company to be a part of!
pros: Great work/life balance. A very harmonious office/work environment. Everyone is very friendly and pleasant. The management team does a great job at holding employee events, both big & small to get us all together whether it's to just have fun or for charitable causes. I actually enjoy coming to work and being a part of this team. I have been an employee for 2 years now and still as happy as when I first started.
cons: None I can think of.

title: Horrible Company to be employed by.
pros: Casual environment....jeans, snickers, head phones, flip flops.
cons: Bad management, very unorganized, no communication. Managers instead of talking to their employees they prefer to hear it, from other people that have nothing to do with that department.

title: Anonymous
pros: Extremely fast-paced as they are growing quickly. If you're up to work hard then this can be an exciting place to work. Benefits are pretty good. Lot of great people working here.
cons: Extremely fast paced. Long hours at times. Ambiguity. Favoritism and nepotism win over skills not always but sometimes.

title: Outstanding Company/ Organization to Work for! American Homes 4 Rent
pros: This is a challenging work environment and is not for the faint of heart or undedicated I will grant all day long, but that honestly is why I thoroughly enjoy and value my job here. I have been with the company for many years and have embraced many changes during the growth of this young company. I stand very proud though to be an employee with AH4R. I enjoy the daily challenges and hurdles in turning a loss into a win! If I'm unsuccessful in something, this simply motivates me to try harder to be #1. Management from my experience has and is very supportive to myself and to those that have commitment to what this company is striving very hard to become! As with anything anywhere, money can always be better, but money is NOT everything! Working for AH4R over my years has proven a blessing in many many ways! I strongly encourage anyone who wants to be dedicated and work for an industry leader to apply and get on board! The sky is truly the limit to what can be accomplished working with AH4R! The Houston Management Team (& all others I've encountered throughout my time and across many areas) and above, I believe is beyond exceptional with the end result of Doing What's Right as our primary daily driver!
cons: Compared to other work I've done in many different industries, I have no complaints or cons to this job! Again, I believe this company is not for everyone, but it is for those that take pride in their work and have a high ethical integrity! It is very disturbing to see the negative reviews from past employees and tenants current and past, as I know 1st hand (at least from my perspective in the Houston office) they are not true. Do we have issues and challenges we are working through? Yes, as anyone does in their daily work environment. But, Anyone that gets hold of me gets an honest and timely response! Granted the response is not always what people want to hear, but it is what's right and not dishonest in any way and I I firmly believe that AH4R is about doing what's right for it's employees and tenants! This I feel is our culture all the way through Senior Mgmt to the very top! This again, at least from my experience! But I am one that doesn't take for granted what I have and I certainly don't want something for nothing! If you want something for nothing, please do move on somewhere else to work!

title: A conundrum, at best.
pros: The pay is relatively good. It is also a relatively relaxed work environment.
cons: Contrary to most reviews, this company, at least in this region, does not promote from within. The company's different departments do not communicate and it causes a general disregard. If you are experienced in property management, you will find they have a different process than most that gives the impression of a call center. The hours are longer than industry standard and more rigid.

title: Staff Accountant
pros: My experience so far has been great! The people on the accounting team are easygoing and will teach you every step of the way. The other employees are also friendly and easy to get along with. Everyone generally gets in by 9 and the office is empty by 6. Compensation seems fair for the position and industry.
cons: There are not that many restaurants nearby. There are no snacks but at least there is coffee and tea.

title: Great place to work!
pros: The accounting team is very professional and employees have many opportunities to be exposed to advanced accounting skills. There are several trainings every week to help employee develop the profession. Most importantly, people and supervisors are wise and friendly. They really help you to grow and are always patient to help you correct your mistakes. Good work-life balance.
cons: Everything is perfect for me and I haven't seen any downside so far.

title: Great Company! Best Job Ever!!
pros: The leadership and growth of this company, have developed an In House Maintenance Department. Leading the team is Travis Buchanan, John Elsey, Jason Salmonson and Lincoln Palmer. During the last year, they have brought on board several experienced Regional Managers that have countless years of experience. Through continued growth, the entire team has worked together developing a great team and system that is continually developing new ways to save the company money. I really love this job, the ability to manage my team, without being micromanaged.
cons: With growth of the IHM department, the Regional Service Managers duties and staff supervision staff count has nearly doubled. It was announced in the 3rd quarter of 2017 that we would be doubling our staffing size and responsibilities. During the announcement, it was also said that with the additional duties and staffing, the Regional Service Managers would be well compensated. However, when our reviews & pay raises were given on January 1st it didn't reflect the added duties and staff count. The raises that were given are the same as other company employees received (2%-5%) that still hold and perform the same responsibilities. I'm happy that I received a raise on Jan. 1st. However, the thing I find hard to accept is the raise I received is the same that I would have received without the added staffing and responsibilities. After reviewing comparable positions in similar industries with similar staff count and supervision, I would have expected around 20%-25% salary increase for the doubling of staff supervision and responsibilities.

title: Growing company with lots of advantages
pros: Family oriented work environment and great pay. Your hard work is recognized and rewarded. You do work hard but it’s a fun very relaxed environment that is not micromanaged. As long as you come to work ready to work, that is the only expectation.
cons: None that I have encountered. Most of the reviews that are written from former employees are from people who got fired. I really doubt that they would have anything positive to say.

title: A joke of a company
pros: Interesting field of work to be in.
cons: They think they can run the whole company from Vegas, so they laid off a bunch of good employees so the robots in vegas can try to do it all. Management wants to micro manage everything instead of having employees who can think for themselves. Oh! and don't ever complain to HR about another employee because they will lay you off, and have you escorted out by the police. HR is a HUGE joke!

title: Enriching Experience
pros: Pushing the boundaries of the industry to stay at the forefront. Training and growth opportunities for all employees. Upper management that listens to concerns and accepts new ideas. I have found my time with AH4R to be deeply rewarding. I started with the company as a maintenance technician and now I'm undertaking the position of District Maintenance Manager for three western markets. I have been given opportunities here that I don't think I would have ever had with a different company. AH4R believes in using internal talent and resources to build a strong organization.
cons: I don't have any cons for this company.

title: Wonderful Company to work for with a Focus on the Employee!!
pros: AH4R is not only Resident focused but a strong focus put on the Employee to ensure every voice is heard AH4R provides additional training for all positions and encourages career growth AH4R has a great compensation/benefits package AH4R provides resources to the Local offices to make our day to day job run smoother
cons: The only CON is I didn't find AH4R sooner in life.

title: Disaster that makes Rich men Richer
pros: You get to say you're part of a new industry
cons: Micromanagement. Executive team will work you to the bone, then fire you when you stop producing. It is a meat-grinder, designed to make the billionaires who buy the home portfolios very wealthy. The company itself, that manages the homes, is really just an afterthought: no vision; no culture; no values. Just slave-drivers who treat renters like commodities to exploit. Turnover is ridiculous. They have to restaff the entire organization every year or two - it's that bad!

title: Fast-paced, fun environment
pros: American Homes 4 Rent is a great company to work for. They train their new hires well and offer a competitive salary. The busy, fast paced nature of the business means no day ever drags and no day is ever the same! The co-workers I have all seem to really enjoy their jobs and we make time to have a little fun during the day too. Also, they try to promote from within whenever possible!
cons: Everything on the leasing side of things is done online, which can be a bit frustrating when technology doesn't want to co-operate.

title: Cultural Shock
pros: To say this is the absolute best company I’ve ever had the pleasure of “working” for would be a false statement. Technically, when you are employed by by American Homes 4 Rent you are a “Part” of something. So, American Homes 4 Rent is the best company I have ever been a “Part” of. Every role being a MAIN ingredient to the growing and adaptive success since its conception. Your voice, your time, your skill set, are consistently adhered to and encouraged. COVID, political, cultural issues, managed so well, we seen growth and inclusion beyond what normal corporate structures hoped to conceptualize. We held meetings on diversity, educated each other on key issues and adopted policies to keep our network of coworkers feeling safe and taken care of. Other companies threw money at the issues, AH4R fed us with empathy and conversation. From top to bottom there is not one employee that wears this logo that isn’t regularly included in big conversations, or reassured of the companies direction. You simply won’t find that type of transparency with ANY big corporations in this country. I’m proud, humbled and endowed everyday I put on my American Homes 4 Rent Swag. This cultural phenomenon shines thru all of us and onto our tenants. Our homes are the best on the market, our staff is the most talented, and the company as a whole is magnanimous. Your career, no matter what your skill set, will be invigorated and bolstered here. The minute you onboard you are family. Not joining us on this journey, will be your biggest regret. It is my sincere hope that anyone that applies gets the esteemed privilege to be assimilated into the greatest team ever assembled. I’m one of the lucky ones. Thank you AH4R for the greatest experience of my adult career. As I look forward to continuing to grow with you and my colleagues.
cons: There’s never any snacks at our team meetings… 🤪

title: Run don't walk
pros: Nice location and great restaurants close to the office
cons: People are not appreciated. Upper management will walk right by you as if you were invisible. Morale is terrible. People are so unhappy. HR is for the company not the employee. I am fed up with the favoritism that I am going to leave even if I don't have a job. You are not judged by your work ethics but who you know If I could give a negative star I would

title: One of the most poorly ran companies
pros: I used the experience to get a better job! Paid training to move upwards in my career. Good health benefits. Pay was decent.
cons: Poor and unqualified management. This company waste a lot of money by firing good people instead of developing and training employees. The reason this is such a problem is because of poor management. There's no good leadership, job stability at this organization, no real growth, no sense of ownership...it's just a job for however long it last. Just use AH4R for the experience and move upwards to something better.

title: Very Satisfied Long Term Employee
pros: American Homes 4 Rent is a company where opportunities abound for a person who is willing to invest the time and effort. AH4R is a growing, stable company with lots of room for advancement. The pay is very fair, the benefits are top notch, and you receive tremendous support from upper management.
cons: Occasionally you encounter a client issue that isn't resolved as quickly or efficiently as you would like to ensure complete customer satisfaction.

title: Poor upper management
pros: There's no pros all are cons.
cons: - poor upper management. - project manager managed more than 40 houses at the same time. - unreasonable targets per quarter & end of year. - no site office & bath for site staff. - most are sitting at home doing nothing except giving lectures without solving major issues & keep loading & blaming project manager - high turn over. You have to be ready to work alone in your neighborhood without any managers on top of you. - loading project managers by tasks out of job description. - poor property management service staff. - no growth potential with high turnover in senior management level. - diversity is just at the junior levels not at the senior levels.

title: Stay away

That office hasn't a clue how the other markets work. Markets will fail if you aren't visible. Amateurs.

title: AH4R
pros: Good pay and free coffee. If you like to help people and don't mind dealing with angry tenants and feel like you have the ability to calm them down and really help them resolve the issue they are having, go for it.
cons: When others call out sick, it takes little time for the calls to pile up, putting 50+ calls in your hands

title: Great place to have fun and get paid
pros: Company is very supportive of In House Maintenance Techs. Great pay, benefits, Paid time off. Corporate office is very helpful in all divisions.
cons: Property management is horrible in our area. No team environment between PM and Techs, “us against them mentality”. The biggest complaint I hear from tenants is that “Property Management does not return phone calls or emails!”

title: Great People, Great Product
pros: AH4R is company commited to continual improvement. The people make all the difference. The company is dedicated to providing employees with opportunity and customers with a great experience. Top down, this company is made up of caring, kind, dedicated people.
cons: The company has grown fast and we sometimes need to react faster to customer issues to provide the best experience possible.

title: Field Superintendent should be titled in house vendor
pros: Great benefits. Company vehicle. Monthly phone allowance.

Extremely poor communication from management. Suspicious activity from upper management involving vendors.

title: Wonderful Place to Work
pros: Managers that I work under are fair and understand you have a real life outside of work. Taking PTO/Sick time isn't met with any scrutiny (it was at my last job), they're happy for you to take a deserved break. Compensation is very good, and they review salaries on a regular bases. Work environment is great, and so is the company's culture. Co-workers are very diverse in background, and culture.
cons: It took awhile from when I applied to when I was initially called, however, I understand that this is par for the course.

title: Truly a great place to work
pros: I work on the communications team. While our team is small, we really work hard to get a lot accomplished. Our VP of Communications, Gemma, is always willing to work with me to meet my professional development. I'm constantly encouraged to take on important projects and supported throughout. Megan, our SVP of Communications, creates the right environment that empowers us to achieve business and performance goals. This company's culture stands out from other places I've worked, and you hear it from everyone working here.
cons: I haven't come across any.

title: Talented employees with no hope for Career advancement
pros: The base pay is decent, and there are a lot of great people that make it easier to get by each day.
cons: The only way to advance in the company is by knowing someone. If you are looking to establish yourself within a company this is not the place to do it.

title: Moms- you can forget about getting promoted
pros: I worked with the best people and felt appreciated at the local level.
cons: If you work in the East Division you will never get promoted if you are a mom of young children or plan on becoming a mom during your employment. If you can actually get a District Manager job, youll never go any further than that. Its rare to even get a leasing manager job if you have underage children.

title: Be VERY Weary!!!
pros: most people were nice, decent pay, cafe located in building
cons: liberal company that will target conservatives, HIGH turner over because they threat there employees as expendable items, most people in this position had mommy and daddy get them this job, upper mgt is a joke and will gas you up about "opportunity", but unless your parents work for the company, good luck. Manager of Acquisitions (my boss) tried to force a pyramid scheme on me during my first 2 weeks. If you find other offers, do yourself a favor and stay away from this place.

title: Good company for those who like to self perform the majority of the SOW
pros: The company provides Transit Van & tools. Company paid PTO Benefits and Quarterly Bonuses Good Field Management
cons: Low hourly pay compared to most companies. Upper Mgmt. always coming up with more self perform work to add to your plate because they want to get rid of using general contractors.

title: Do NOT waste your time or mental health on this company
pros: The pros are you have a large portfolio
cons: - HORRIBLE training platform - HORRIBLE management in Charlotte - Sexist and female dominant environment and retaliatory when you bring up an issue - Maintenance requests go weeks without attention which puts your real estate license in jeopardy - Lack of compassion for residents, they just dangle credits to shut up residents - Lack of communication and customer service

title: Burned out to the max
pros: Nice people you will come across. You may have one day off a week. You will start drinking more and smoking (that is if you like that kind of stuff).
cons: overworked and not appreciated. long hours and not enough home time. every month you will have bad mouthing from upper management. HR is not reliable or useful to stop unethical behavior.

title: Field Superintendent
pros: American Homes 4 Rent is not just a job with co-workers it's a job with family and people who cares about you and want to see you learn and grown. It so much support from everyone in every position.
cons: The downside for me would be the crazy Florida weather. When working out in the field and it's over a 100 degrees outside it could be a little miserable.

title: Great Opportunity to Make an Impact
pros: American Homes 4 Rent is a fast-growing company that does a great job identifying and recruiting talent. They allow employees with appropriate experience to make an impact in the day to day operations of the company while creating a great company culture.

title: GAWD AWFUL PLACE!
pros: Do you like being reprimanded for working too hard? Do you like being given completely wrong information by trainers and leads? Do you like being given information from managers who completely contradict one another on a regular basis? Do you like being penalized for that wrong or contradictory information even when you can prove that it was given to you by a trainer/lead/manager? Do you like being penalized for not adhering to a change in policy weeks before the change is actually implemented? Do you like being left out of important meetings and then penalized for not knowing information that was covered during those meetings? Are you absolutely impervious to any form of injury or illness with Superman-like guarantees? If you answered yes to any of these questions, then American Homes 4 Rent is the place for you!
cons: Don't get sick. Like, ever. This company does not offer any sick days at all. You can literally be wheeled out of the building on a stretcher and loaded into an ambulance and you will still get an occurrence for it. While working here, I saw three separate instances where people had to be wheeled out of this place by EMT's in the same calendar year! That can't be normal. Do you know how many ambulances I saw when I worked at the MGM Grand offices just down the street from this place? ZERO! It's like this place makes people sick - with all the gas leaks and the fires in the ventilation systems and the AC unit catching fire it actually wouldn't surprise me if this building really were toxic! Also, don't drive yourself to work if you're hired here. Trust me on this. Unless you manage to pull a shift that starts before 7 a.m. you WILL NOT find parking anywhere on company property. The company does offer an overflow parking option across the street and down a spell but it fills up too. If, and only if, all of the parking spots in both lots are full, are you then permitted to park on the curbs - but if a spot opens up while you're working ... LOOK OUT! The company sends the front desk secretary out every single day with a clipboard to see who's parked on the curb and whether or not there are spots open. If your car is on the curb and there's a spot open - she calls a tow truck. I'm not joking, I saw multiple cars get towed while working here. So if you're forced to park on the curb and you're not lucky enough to have a window seat overlooking the parking lot so you can monitor the availability of parking spaces, you become forced to find ways to check on the parking lot at every opportunity. Breaks, lunch, on your way to a meeting. Whatever it takes, so that if a spot opens up you can run out there and move your car into it, and the whole time you're trying to convince your lead or supervisor to let you leave your desk to move your car, you're simultaneously hoping someone else doesn't come back from lunch, park in that spot, and make all of your efforts completely moot. There is also a really odd ratio of black to white management. Hear me out because there are some messed up numbers here. In the call center alone, 10 out of 11 leads are either black or mixed race and the 11th lead is latino. That in and of itself is suspect but it's also a lot better than if they were all white. RIght? But then you look at the upper-management and it starts to become clear if not worrisome. All but one of the supervisors and upper-management in the call center is white and it's the same thing in the maintenance department. Almost all of the leads are black, hispanic, and mixed but all of the supervisors and upper-management are white. Does that seem fishy to you? BTW, FYI - there is absolutely no financial benefit to being a lead. You don't get paid more but you have to meet the same quota requirements as a normal agent in order to earn your bonus. Howver, as a lead you spend less time on the phone and therefore are less likely to qualify for even the minimum bonus. In essence, leads make less money than regular agents do but it's all cleverly disguised under the guise of 'equal opportunity employment and advancement'. Right. To my knowledge, none of the current supervisors in any of the aforementioned departments were promoted to supervisor positions from 'lead' positions. They were either hired fresh as supervisors or promoted directly from agent to supervisor. When you examine all the facts, the position of lead seems to be a place where they put you if they want to appease affirmative action without actually giving you a real promotion. Another thing about being promoted or advancing. The supervisor's bonus is dependent upon the bonus's of the agents under them which means the more agents that qualify for the max bonus on a supervisors team, the more likely that supervisor is to get the max bonus as well. Seems fair right? Until you, again, look at who's being 'promoted' to lead positions or until you want to transfer to a different department. Most of the top 10 performers in Customer Service have been with the company for close to or more than a year but most of the leads were hired less than a year ago. Sure, it's likely that those top performers don't want to be leads because they want that bonus ... but if you actually ask them about it, most of them have never even been given the option. Clearly they know what they're doing and they have seniority, so why did the company decide to 'promote' someone who calls in sick or leaves early every time she menstruates and couldn't pass a drug test if her life depended on it? Because if they promote their top performers, those supervisors are in danger of losing their max bonus - and it's the same thing if you try to advance to a different department. Oh it's cleverly concealed behind yards of red tape, excuses, bald-faced lies, accusations, and even blatant avoidance, but if you're persistent enough all of those one-off coincidences start to look a heck of a lot more like intentional sabotage. And don't bother telling HR because they'll just argue with you and overlook it. And while it's okay to be a top performer and do the best job that they want you to do, please don't actually try to do the best job that you can because then you become a threat and you'll be told to stop. Don't offer to be helpful, don't volunteer for extra assignments, and for the love of all that is holy, whatever you do, don't actually try to HELP a customer. That is not your job. It doesn't matter what department you work in, your job is NOT to help the tenants or answer any questions for them at all. Your job is to ask them a bunch of questions while refusing to answer any questions in return. Promise them a call back from their property manager or a maintenance coordinator, or a supervisor, or even the Pope if you must. It doesn't really matter who because no one will ever call them back anyway, and then get them off your phone within the magical 5 to 7 minute time frame that allows you to take the coveted 60 calls per day in order to earn your max bonus. If you actually try to answer their question or help them with a problem, then you're violating company procedures and codes of conduct. And then there's the tenants! They're all angry. ALL of them. They're angry and they want someone to take it out on and your job is to just take it. It doesn't matter if you're in sales, customer service, maintenance, property management, HOA, or even leasing. Everyone who deals with this company for any length of time eventually becomes terrifyingly angry and frustrated and they will take it out on every single person that they can actually get to answer a phone. Most call centers will allow you to disconnect if a caller becomes verbally abusive, uses profanity and/or racial slurs, or threatens you. Not this place. Nope. You're expected to take it and if you just can't take it anymore and you need to transfer it to the escalations line (because they do have an escalations line) you must first inform a lead and they'll just tell you to try harder to de-escalate because they don't want to take the call either. But really, the misery of the tenants pales in comparison to the internal politics. The different departments in this company are conditioned to hate each other and blame each other for everything so that the company as a whole never takes any blame. Ever. Tenants hate their property managers, property managers hate maintenance coordinators, maintenance coordinators hate customer service, and customer service hates everyone. Anywhere in the building you go at any given time you will encounter people from one department or another talking bad about the other departments every single day of the week. No one is happy. The people who like their job or like working here have either not been here long enough or they've learned to just stop caring. Show up, do what you're told, take your reprimands with your mouth shut even when their unjustified, don't ask questions, don't have any ambition - just collect your paycheck and go home. It's the only way to survive here.

title: Jobseeker/Employee Beware
pros: During my time at AH4R I made some amazing acquaintances....
cons: The Culture: During my time at AH4R I made some amazing acquaintances. I use the word acquaintances intentionally. You will need to foster your relationships very carefully as your connections with others may be perceived as a threat, you might be scrutinized for who you acquaint yourself with, or you may even be accused of organizing. In short, the culture at this company is a concert of high school theatrics, toxicity, and should only be regarded as highly dysfunctional from the top down. Specifically, if you are a person of a protected class be aware wide spread discrimination and retaliation of complaints. Growth Opportunities: There is no room for advancement within this organization even when you do everything right. They will hire who they want, for what position they want, for the salary they want if they “like” them. Be prepared to negotiate your pay, because if you are paid one penny over what they deem to be your worth, it will cost you, if you are bonus eligible, remember its “discretionary”. For eligible salaried employees, at performance review you will be told to lower your self-evaluation so to fall in line with a standard, companywide, annual pay increase generally 3% , if they “like you” maybe more, but then again they have no metrics for the bonus its “discretionary”. Benefits: Typically industry standard, no perks, and certainly no work life balance, don’t let anyone try to convince you of these lies. If you try to use FMLA/ADA protections, you will be targeted and ultimately fired, unless your white, in which case you are encouraged to leverage these protections. Should you ever challenge or simply question the operational efficiency, management, practices, ethics, law, or more specifically your rights? It gets worse. If you are a person in a protected class it is common place practice that you are treated differently, this treatment frequently becomes increasingly hostile and directly discriminant in nature. Should you try to utilize the internal complaint process or open door policy, that is the very instant you become a target of retaliation. It starts with memos to file, that you wouldn’t even know about. Next, you might find yourself on PIP, stacked with remedial and inaccurate details and then a meeting with a member of the HR team only to be reminded that you live in a “Right to Work” State. For some employees the realization that where they work is not somewhere that everyone can “feel right at home” becomes apparent in a matter of days. For others, they see the discriminant treatment happening within a few weeks, “What happened to so and so and so and so ?” Here one day and gone the next. For, those that have survived their first year and maybe the annual evaluation, they might think: “Well they like me, they have not done anything like that to me”, “They wouldn’t do anything like that to me”. Be advised, your number just has not come up yet! The bad reviews are ALL true. The good reviews are fake. This company solicits current employees to write good reviews on their behalf. About 50% of the employees have been around since day one and most are complicit or suffering from job inertia, the other 50% is year over year turnover. Why would you need an entire team of recruiters when you average 500+ hiring of employees year over year, yet remain at the same 1200 or so employees nationwide year after year? You guessed right! Turnover, that’s why. For those considering joining the team: do not be lured by the promise of great work environment, bonuses, growth advancement, great benefits and diversity. For those that are still there: don’t be fooled by the promise of the promotion that will never come, the freedom to gain experience by way of internal promotion, or meetings about inclusion and diversity. It is all for show, a farse a best, but you already know that. For the survivors, you were not and you are still not alone, cheers to your betterment and healing.

title: Wished it could have been better.
pros: Working with a great team of coworkers.
cons: In my opinion it is clear that this organization has no regard for its employees' well-being or sustainable and valuable professional development. Making money and improving existing processes isn’t enough, they have a “tear it all down and start again” approach that seems to come around every couple of years, placing blame on its people and their obligations to shareholders and investors. For such a young company, the amount of change is so overwhelming that there isn’t enough time to excel at anything before leadership makes another loosely informed pivot, driven by spreadsheets, reports, and external pressures, rather than real world applications and accurate data. It's quite apparent that the company is chronically understaffed by reading its reviews and hearing from its people, leading to unrealistic expectations, which have resulted in an exceedingly negative work environment. The lack of resources and support within the company is concerning, as it creates an environment where employees are forced to make do with what they have and salaried employees can only work longer hours leading to further stress and burnout. Leadership disguises these issues as challenges to overcome, however at this level they’re blockades to any real progress or refinement. The favoritism shown by the company is abhorrent and demotivating, leading to a culture where it seems like only a select few are valued, appreciated, mentored, promoted, and cared for. This, coupled with the lack of patient, supportive, and motivating leadership, has created a toxic workplace that seems to be going nowhere fast and is upending in chaos. It is unsurprising that the company appears to be experiencing significant attrition rates, given the severe problems outlined. It's quite evident that the company is not interested in investing in its employees, leading to a revolving door of talent that ultimately hurts the company's bottom line. There have been so many widely known management departures that I am surprised people would still apply to work there. In the interest of checking boxes, they mandated diversity, leadership, and ethics trainings to garner bragging rights for training and leadership development, while pandering for their highly coveted “Great Place to Work” designation. Unfortunately, that survey does little to quantify or address the actual problems this organization has, electing to only pay attention to the demographical and social virtue signaling of the survey fueling the lions share of that designation. Simplified: Great Place to Work doesn’t mean what you think it does. A couple of years ago the company expended some effort trying to convince its employees that they care with some new benefits, an emphasis on culture, and raises to elevate current and prospective employees to the market rate. This was encouraging, but since then they have adopted a “return on investment” approach by shrinking budgets, staff, and placing more emphasis on squeezing every dollar out of everyone and everything. It has removed any sense of culture, fun, pride, and genuine pleasure working there. In conclusion, I would not recommend this company to anyone. The numerous issues that it's currently facing are indicative of a company that does not value its employees or their contributions.
